[[File:Bundle adjustment sparse matrix.png|right|thumb|A sparse matrix obtained when solving a modestly sized bundle adjustment problem. This is the sparsity pattern of a 992×992 normal-equation (i.e. approximate Hessian) matrix. Black regions correspond to nonzero blocks.]] Given a set of images depicting a number of 3D points from [[stereoscopy|different viewpoints]], '''bundle adjustment''' can be defined as the problem of simultaneously refining the 3D [[Coordinate system|coordinates]] describing the scene geometry, the parameters of the relative motion, and the optical characteristics of the camera(s) employed to acquire the images, according to an optimality criterion involving the [[Correspondence problem|corresponding]] image projections of all points.
==Uses== Bundle adjustment is almost always used as the last step of every feature-based [[3D reconstruction]] algorithm. It amounts to an optimization problem on the 3D structure and viewing parameters (i.e., camera [[Pose (computer vision)|pose]] and possibly intrinsic calibration and radial distortion), to obtain a reconstruction which is optimal under certain assumptions regarding the noise pertaining to the observed<ref name="triggs1999">{{cite conference | title=Bundle Adjustment — A Modern Synthesis | author=B. Triggs |author2=P. McLauchlan |author3=R. Hartley |author4=A. Fitzgibbon | booktitle=ICCV '99: Proceedings of the International Workshop on Vision Algorithms | pages=298–372 | doi=10.1007/3-540-44480-7_21 | isbn=3-540-67973-1 | publisher=Springer-Verlag | year=1999 }}</ref> image features: If the image error is zero-mean [[Gaussian noise|Gaussian]], then bundle adjustment is the [[Maximum likelihood|Maximum Likelihood Estimator]].<ref name="sba2009">{{cite journal | title=SBA: A Software Package for Generic Sparse Bundle Adjustment | author=M.I.A. Lourakis and A.A. Argyros | journal=ACM Transactions on Mathematical Software | pages=1–30 | volume=36 | issue=1 | doi=10.1145/1486525.1486527 | publisher=ACM | year=2009 }}</ref>{{rp|2}} Its name refers to the bundles of light rays originating from each 3D feature and converging on each [[Pinhole camera model|camera's]] optical center, which are adjusted optimally with respect to both the structure and viewing parameters (similarity in meaning to [[category (mathematics)|categorical]] [[bundle (mathematics)|bundle]] seems a pure coincidence). Bundle adjustment was originally conceived in the field of [[photogrammetry]] during the 1950s and has increasingly been used by [[computer vision]] researchers during recent years.<ref name="sba2009" />{{rp|2}}
==General approach== Bundle adjustment boils down to minimizing the [[reprojection error]] between the image locations of observed and predicted image points, which is expressed as the sum of squares of a large number of nonlinear, real-valued functions. Thus, the minimization is achieved using nonlinear [[least-squares]] algorithms. Of these, [[Levenberg–Marquardt algorithm|Levenberg–Marquardt]] has proven to be one of the most successful due to its ease of implementation and its use of an effective damping strategy that lends it the ability to converge quickly from a wide range of initial guesses. By iteratively linearizing the function to be minimized in the neighborhood of the current estimate, the Levenberg–Marquardt algorithm involves the solution of [[System of linear equations|linear systems]] termed the [[Linear least squares (mathematics)|normal equations]]. When solving the minimization problems arising in the framework of bundle adjustment, the normal equations have a [[Sparse matrix|sparse]] block structure owing to the lack of interaction among parameters for different 3D points and cameras. This can be exploited to gain tremendous computational benefits by employing a sparse variant of the Levenberg–Marquardt algorithm which explicitly takes advantage of the normal equations zeros pattern, avoiding storing and operating on zero-elements.<ref name="sba2009" />{{rp|3}}
==Mathematical definition== Bundle adjustment amounts to jointly refining a set of initial camera and structure parameter estimates for finding the set of parameters that most accurately predict the locations of the observed points in the set of available images. More formally,<ref>{{cite book | author=R.I. Hartley and A. Zisserman | title=Multiple View Geometry in computer vision | publisher=Cambridge University Press | edition=2nd | year=2004 | isbn=0-521-54051-8 }}</ref> assume that <math>n</math> 3D points are seen in <math>m</math> views and let <math>\mathbf{x}_{ij}</math> be the projection of the <math>i</math>th point on image <math>j</math>. Let <math>\displaystyle v_{ij}</math> denote the binary variables that equal 1 if point <math>i</math> is visible in image <math>j</math> and 0 otherwise. Assume also that each camera <math>j</math> is parameterized by a vector <math>\mathbf{a}_j</math> and each 3D point <math>i</math> by a vector <math>\mathbf{b}_i</math>. Bundle adjustment minimizes the total reprojection error with respect to all 3D point and camera parameters, specifically
:<math> \min_{\mathbf{a}_j, \, \mathbf{b}_i} \displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^{n} \; \displaystyle\sum_{j=1}^{m} \; v_{ij} \, d(\mathbf{Q}(\mathbf{a}_j, \, \mathbf{b}_i), \; \mathbf{x}_{ij})^2, </math>
where <math>\mathbf{Q}(\mathbf{a}_j, \, \mathbf{b}_i)</math> is the predicted [[camera matrix|projection]] of point <math>i</math> on image <math>j</math> and <math>d(\mathbf{x}, \, \mathbf{y})</math> denotes the Euclidean distance between the image points represented by vectors <math>\mathbf{x}</math> and <math>\mathbf{y}</math>. Clearly, bundle adjustment is by definition tolerant to missing image projections and minimizes a physically meaningful criterion.
==Software== * [http://logiciels.ign.fr/?Telechargement,20]: Apero/MicMac, a free open source photogrammetric software. Cecill-B licence. * [http://www.ics.forth.gr/~lourakis/sba/ sba]: A Generic Sparse Bundle Adjustment C/C++ Package Based on the Levenberg–Marquardt Algorithm ([[C (programming language)|C]], [[MATLAB]]). GPL. * [http://www.uco.es/investiga/grupos/ava/node/39/ cvsba]: An OpenCV wrapper for [http://www.ics.forth.gr/~lourakis/sba/ sba] library ([[C++]]). GPL. * [https://github.com/royshil/SfM-Toy-Library/tree/335d7d2a0c1e603ec994d0e025bdec8ebeb493bc/3rdparty/SSBA-3.0 ssba]: Simple Sparse Bundle Adjustment package based on the Levenberg–Marquardt Algorithm (C++). LGPL. * [http://opencv.org/ OpenCV]: Computer Vision library in the [http://docs.opencv.org/3.2.0/d1/d46/group__stitching.html Images stitching] module. BSD license. * [http://grail.cs.washington.edu/projects/mcba/ mcba]: Multi-Core Bundle Adjustment (CPU/GPU). GPL3. * [https://github.com/dkogan/libdogleg libdogleg]: General-purpose sparse non-linear least squares solver, based on Powell's dogleg method. LGPL. * [http://ceres-solver.org/ ceres-solver]: A Nonlinear Least Squares Minimizer. BSD license. * [http://openslam.org/g2o.html g2o]: General Graph Optimization (C++) - framework with solvers for sparse graph-based non-linear error functions. LGPL. * [http://www.ifp.uni-stuttgart.de/publications/software/openbundle/index.en.html DGAP]: The program DGAP implement the photogrammetric method of bundle adjustment invented by Helmut Schmid and Duane Brown. GPL. * [https://www.cs.cornell.edu/~snavely/bundler/ Bundler]: A structure-from-motion (SfM) system for unordered image collections (for instance, images from the Internet) by Noah Snavely. GPL.

{{Infobox mountain | name = Carrauntoohil | other_name = '''''Corrán Tuathail''''' | photo = Carrauntoohil 2016.JPG | photo_caption = Carrauntoohil's east face (l), and north-east face (r, in shadow), as seen from the Hag's Glen. | photo_size = | elevation = {{convert|1038.6|m|abbr=off}} | elevation_ref =<ref name="osi mountains">{{cite web |url=http://www.osi.ie/Education/Primary-Schools/Seniors/Mountains,-Rivers-Lakes-(1).aspx |title=Mountains, Rivers & Lakes |publisher=[[Ordnance Survey Ireland]] |year=2012 |accessdate=4 August 2012}}</ref> | prominence = {{convert|1038.6|m|ft|abbr=on}} | prominence_ref = <ref name="osi mountains"/> | map = island of Ireland | map_relief = yes | map_caption = Location in Ireland | map_size = 300 | label_position = none | listing = [[List of countries by highest point|Country high point]], [[List of Irish counties by highest point|County top (Kerry)]], [[List of P600 mountains in the British Isles|P600]], [[List of Marilyns in the British Isles|Marilyn]], [[List of Furth mountains in the British Isles|Furth]], [[List of Hewitt mountains in England, Wales and Ireland|Hewitt]], [[Lists of mountains in Ireland#Arderins|Arderin]], [[List of mountains of the British Isles by height|Simm]], [[Lists of mountains in Ireland#Vandeleur-Lynams|Vandeleur-Lynam]] | translation = Tuathal's sickle | language = [[Irish language|Irish]] | location = [[County Kerry]], [[Ireland]] | range = [[MacGillycuddy's Reeks]] | coordinates = {{coord|51.999447|N|9.742744|W|type:mountain_scale:100000|format=dms|display=inline,title}} | coordinates_ref = | grid_ref_Ireland = V803844 | topo = [[Ordnance Survey of Ireland|OSI]] ''Discovery'' 78 | type= Purple sandstone & siltstone | easiest_route = ''Devil's Ladder'' (via ''Hag's Glen'') | period=[[Devonian]] }}
'''Carrauntoohil''' ({{IPAc-en|ˌ|k|ær|ə|n|ˈ|t|uː|l}},{{nbsp}}{{lga|Corrán Tuathail|Tuathal's sickle}})<ref name="pdi">{{cite web |url=http://www.logainm.ie/?text=Carrauntoohil |title=Carrauntoohil|publisher=[[logainm.ie|Placenames Database of Ireland]]|accessdate=2010-01-28}}</ref><ref name="peak">{{cite web|url= http://www.mountaineering.ie/_files/Paul%20Tempan%20Irish%20Mountain%20Placenames%20-%20Feb%202012.pdf|title=Irish Hill and Mountain Names|publisher=MountainViews.ie|author=Paul Tempan|date=February 2012}}</ref> is the [[Lists of mountains in Ireland|highest mountain]] on the island of [[Ireland]] at {{convert|1038.6|m|ft}}. Located in [[County Kerry]], Carrauntoohil is the central peak of the [[MacGillycuddy's Reeks]], Ireland's highest mountain range.<ref name="jimr"/>
==Geology== {{Main article|MacGillycuddy's Reeks#Geology}}
Carrauntoohil is composed of sandstone particles of various sizes which are collectively known as ''[[Old Red Sandstone]]''.<ref name="jimr"/> Old Red Sandstone has a purple–reddish colour (stained green in places), and has virtually no fossils.<ref name="jimr"/><ref name="MAS"/> Carrauntoohil was subject to significant glaciation the result of which are deep fracturing of the rock, and the surrounding of Carrauntoohil by [[U-shaped valley]]s, sharp [[arête]]s, and deep [[cirque|corries]].<ref name="jimr"/>
==Geography==
Carrauntoohil is the central peak of the MacGillycuddy's Reeks, and has three major ridges.<ref name="collins">{{cite book| author=[[MountainViews Online Database]] (Simon Stewart)|year=2013 | title=A Guide to Ireland's Mountain Summits: The Vandeleur-Lynams & the Arderins |publisher=Collins Books | isbn=978-1-84889-164-7}}</ref> A narrow rocky ridge, or [[arête]], to the north, known as the ''[[Beenkeragh Ridge]]'', summits [[The Bones]] (''Na Cnámha''), and leads to Ireland's second-highest peak, [[Beenkeragh]] (''Binn Chaorach'') at {{convert|1,008|m|ft|abbr=on}}. The ridge westward, called the ''[[Caher Ridge]]'', also an [[arête]], leads to Ireland's third-highest peak, [[Caher (mountain)|Caher]] at {{convert|1,000|m|ft|abbr=on}}. A third and much wider, but unnamed, south-easterly ridge, or [[Spur (topography)|spur]], leads down to a [[col]] where sits the top of the ''Devil's Ladder'' (a classic access route for Carrauntoohil from the ''Hag's Glen''), but then rises back up to [[Cnoc na Toinne]] {{convert|845|m|ft|abbr=on}}, from which the long easterly ridge section of the MacGillycuddy's Reeks is accessed.<ref name="dillon">{{cite book | last1 = Dillion | first1 = Paddy | title = The Mountains of Ireland: A Guide to Walking the Summits | publisher = Cicerone | isbn = 978-1852841102 | year = 1993}}</ref><ref name="jimr">{{cite book | last1 = Ryan | first1 = Jim | title = Carrauntoohil and MacGillycuddy's Reeks: A Walking Guide to Ireland's Highest Mountains | publisher = Collins Press | isbn = 978-1905172337 | year = 2006 }}</ref>
[[File:Carrauntoohil Group from Cruach Mhor.jpg|thumb|upright=1.4|left|Looking directly at Carrauntoohil's Eagle's Nest corrie (in shade), surrounded by Carrauntoohil (left), [[The Bones]] and the [[Beenkeragh Ridge]] (centre, back), [[Beenkeragh]] (right), and the ''[[Hag's Tooth, Kerry|Hag's Tooth]]'', and the ''[[Hag's Tooth Ridge]]'' up to Beenkeragh (right). The ''three levels'' of the ''Eagle's Nest'' corrie can be clearly seen.]]
Carrauntoohil overlooks three [[U-shaped valley]]s, each with their own lakes. To the east is Hag's Glen (''Com Caillí'', "hollow of the [[Cailleach]]"), to the west is Coomloughra (''Com Luachra'', "hollow of the rushes") and to the south is Curragh More (''Currach Mór'', "great marsh").<ref name="jimr"/><ref name="dillon"/>
{{anchor|Eagle's Nest}}Carrauntoohil has a deep [[cirque|corrie]], known as the ''Eagle's Nest'', at its north-east face,<ref name="jimr"/> which is accessed from the ''Hag's Glen'', and rises up through three levels. At the top, the ''third level'', is Lough Cummeenoughter, Ireland's highest lake.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/life-and-style/travel/ireland/fancy-a-swim-in-ireland-s-highest-lake-halfway-up-carrauntoohil-1.3538867|title=Fancy a swim in Ireland’s highest lake, halfway up Carrauntoohil?|publisher=[[Irish Times]]|author=Helen Fairborn|date=30 June 2018|quote=Located at an elevation of 707m, Lough Cummeenoughter in Co Kerry is a unique swimming spot. Not only is this the highest lake in Ireland, it’s also one of the most dramatic. Nestled at the base of a natural amphitheatre with the country’s two tallest peaks towering on either side, Irish swimming doesn’t come any wilder than this. The lake itself is surprisingly hospitable; it has a sandy bed and becomes deep quickly enough to dive into.}}</ref> From the ''Eagle's Nest'', the main gullies of Carrauntoohil's north-east face can be seen, being: ''Curved Gully'', ''Central Gully'', and ''Brother O'Shea's Gully''.<ref name="kmr2">{{cite web|url=http://kerrymountainrescue.ie/carrauntoohil-route-descriptions/|title=CARRAUNTOOHIL ROUTE DESCRIPTIONS: BROTHER O'SHEA'S GULLY (LOUGH CUMMEENOUGHTER) ROUTE|publisher=Kerry Mountain Rescue|date=2018}}</ref> Sometimes the term ''Eagle's Nest'' is used to refer to the small stone Mountain Rescue Hut that sits on the ''first level'' of the corrie, where the ''[[Carrauntoohil#Heavenly Gates|Heavenly Gates]]'' descent gully meets the ''Eagle's Nest'' corrie.<ref name="jimr"/>
Carrauntoohil is the highest mountain in Ireland on all [[Lists of mountains in Ireland|classification scales]].<ref name="collins"/><ref name="dobih"/> It is the [[List of mountains of the British Isles by height|133rd–highest mountain, and 4th most prominent mountain]], in Britain and Ireland, on the [[Lists of mountains and hills in the British Isles#Simms|Simms]] classification.<ref name="dobih">{{cite web|url=http://www.hills-database.co.uk/downloads.html|title=The Database of British and Irish Hills|date=2018|author1=Chris Cocker|author2=Graham Jackson|publisher=[[Database of British and Irish Hills]]}}</ref> Carrauntoohil is regarded by the [[Scottish Mountaineering Club]] ("SMC") as one of 34 [[Lists of mountains and hills in the British Isles#Furths|Furths]], which is a mountain above {{convert|3000|ft|0|abbr=on}} in elevation, and meets the other SMC criteria for a [[Munro]] (e.g. "sufficient separation"), but which is outside of (or ''furth'') Scotland;<ref>[http://www.smc.org.uk/Hillwalking/HillKeyFacts.php ''Mountains – Key Facts. The Munros, Corbetts, Grahams, Donalds & Furths''] {{Webarchive|url=https://www.webcitation.org/6AQXbX3qZ?url=http://www.smc.org.uk/Hillwalking/HillKeyFacts.php# |date=2012-09-04 }} at www.smc.org.uk. Accessed on 5 Feb 2013.</ref> which is why Carrauntoohil is referred to as one of the 13 [[Irish Munro]]s.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.smc.org.uk/hills/hill-lists#furths|title=Hill Lists: Furths|quote=The list of peaks of 3000ft or more within the United Kingdom and the Republic of Ireland outside (furth) of Scotland. There are currently 34 Furths.|publisher=[[Scottish Mountaineering Club]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.irelandsown.ie/irelands-munros/|title=Ireland's Munros|publisher=Ireland's Own|date=26 June 2018}}</ref>
Carrauntoohil's larger prominence qualifies it to meet the [[Lists of mountains and hills in the British Isles#P600 (the "Majors")|P600]] classification and the Britain and Ireland [[Lists of mountains and hills in the British Isles#Marilyns|Marilyn]] classification.<ref name="dobih"/> Carrauntoohil is the highest mountain in the [[MountainViews Online Database]], ''[[Lists of mountains in Ireland#100 Highest|100 Highest Irish Mountains]]''.<ref name="mountain">{{cite web|url=https://mountainviews.ie/lists/highest/|title=Irish Highest 100: The highest 100 Irish mountains with a prominence of +100m|publisher=[[MountainViews Online Database]]|date=September 2018}}</ref><ref name="collins"/>
==Summit== [[File:The summit of Carrauntoohil - geograph.org.uk - 331996.jpg|thumb|left|The summit of Carrauntoohil]] A wooden [[Christian cross|cross]] was erected on the summit, a privately owned [[Common land|commonage]], in the 1950s by the local community.<ref name="examiner dec 2014"/> In 1976 it was replaced by a {{convert|5|m|ft|abbr=in}} steel cross. In 2014, the cross was cut down by unknown persons in protest against the [[Catholic Church in Ireland|Catholic Church]],<ref>{{cite web |title=Vandals cut down iconic Cross on Ireland's highest mountain |publisher=BreakingNews.ie |date=2014-11-22 |url=http://www.breakingnews.ie/ireland/vandals-cut-down-iconic-cross-on-irelands-highest-mountain-652017.html |accessdate=22 November 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Video of the Carrauntoohil Cross being cut down sent to journalists |publisher=[[TheJournal.ie]] |date=2 December 2014 |url=http://www.thejournal.ie/carrauntoohil-cross-3-1810988-Dec2014/ |accessdate=15 December 2016}}</ref> but it was re-erected shortly after.<ref name="examiner dec 2014">{{cite web |title=Carrauntoohil cross restored in dawn mission |publisher=IrishExaminer.com |date=1 December 2014|url=http://www.irishexaminer.com/ireland/carrauntoohil-cross-restored-in-dawn-mission-300265.html |accessdate=9 January 2015}}</ref>
Because of the dangers of the steep north-east and east faces of Carrauntoohil, Kerry Mountain Rescue ("KMR") have placed danger signs on the summit, and particularly above the ''Howling Ridge'' sector (the ridge between the north-east and east faces), whose initial section can be mistaken for a hill-walkers descent route.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/life-and-style/travel/ireland/chaos-on-carrauntoohil-too-few-guides-too-late-starting-1.3401951|title=Chaos on Carrauntoohil: Too few guides, too late starting|publisher=[[Irish Times]]|author=Lorna Siggins|date=24 February 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.irishexaminer.com/ireland/hillwalkers-at-risk-by-ignoring-danger-sign-223761.html|title=Hillwalkers at risk by ignoring danger sign|date=26 February 2013|publisher=[[Irish Examiner]]|quote=Hillwalkers ignoring a sign warning them to stay away from potentially dangerous paths near the summit of Ireland’s highest mountain are putting themselves in serious danger. The Kerry Mountain Rescue Team (KMRT) is concerned about a rising number of accidents and rescues on the northern and eastern sides of Carrantuohill. The warning sign, with a skull and crossbones, is on the summit of the mountain.|author=Donal Hickey}}</ref>
==Name==
'Carrauntoohil' is the common spelling and used by [[Ordnance Survey Ireland]].<ref name="peak"/> Others include 'Carrantoohil', 'Carrantouhil', 'Carrauntouhil' and 'Carrantuohill', which are an [[Anglicisation|anglicisations]] of an [[Irish language|Irish]] placename. Paul Tempan's ''Irish Hill and Mountain Names'' (2010) notes that "its name is shrouded in uncertainty", and that "Unlike some lesser peaks, such as Mangerton or Croagh Patrick, it is not mentioned in any surviving early Irish texts".<ref name="peak"/> The official Irish name is ''Corrán Tuathail'', which Tempan notes is interpreted as "Tuathal's sickle", Tuathal being a male first name.<ref name="peak"/> [[Patrick Weston Joyce]] previously interpreted it as "inverted sickle".<ref name="peak"/> However, one of the earliest written accounts of the mountain, by [[Isaac Weld]] in 1812, calls it 'Gheraun-Tuel',<ref name="peak"/> and [[Samuel Lewis (publisher)|Samuel Lewis's]] ''Topographical Dictionary of Ireland'' (1837) calls it 'Garran Tual'.<ref>Lewis, Samuel (1837). [https://www.libraryireland.com/topog/K/Knockane-Dunkerron-Kerry.php "Knockane"]. ''A Topographical Dictionary of Ireland''. Library Ireland.</ref> This suggests that the first element was ''géarán'' ("fang")—which is found in the names of other Kerry mountains—and that the earlier name may have been ''Géarán Tuathail'' ("Tuathal's fang").<ref name="peak"/><ref>Hendroff, Adrian. ''From High Places: A Journey Through Ireland's Great Mountains''. History Press Ireland, 2012. p.220</ref>
==Ownership==
Climber and author Jim Ryan noted in his 2006 book, ''Carrauntoohil and MacGillycuddy’s Reeks'', that the actual mountain of Carrauntoohil, including most of the Hag's Glen, is in private ownership.<ref name="jimr"/> The freehold is owned by four families: Donal Doona, John O'Shea, John B. Doona, and James Sullivan. Their great-grandfathers bought the land from the ''[[Irish Land Commission]]'', "paying the sum of eleven shillings and two cents (70 cents in today's money), twice a year for many decades".<ref name="jimr"/> Ryan's book commended the owners for providing access over the years,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.irishexaminer.com/ireland/praise-for-carrauntoohil-owners-in-walkers-guide-18775.html|title=Praise for Carrauntoohil owners in walkers’ guide|publisher=[[Irish Examiner]]|date=21 November 2006|author=Eoin English|quote=He praised landowners Donal Doona, John O’Shea, John B Doona, James Sullivan and Michael O’Sullivan for allowing public access to their lands on and around Carrauntoohil and the Macgillycuddy’s Reeks over the years. “They are amongst the most welcoming people in the country,” he said. He met the men, their families and recorded their history and association with the lands for the book.}}</ref> despite damage to their farms.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.irishexaminer.com/ireland/dogs-banned-from-carrantuohill-238367.html|title=Dogs banned from Carrauntoohil|publisher=[[Irish Examiner]]|date=31 July 2013|author=Donal Hickey|quote=Carrantuohill is actually owned by private landowners and some people don’t realise that. The owners mainly earn their livelihoods from the land through farming.}}</ref>
A State–sponsored report into access for the range in December 2013 titled ''MacGillycuddy Reeks Mountain Access Development Assessment'' (also called the Mountain Access Project, or MAP), mapped the complex network of land titles.<ref name="MAS"/> Unlike many other national mountain ranges, the MacGillycuddy's Reeks are not part of a national park or a trust structure, and are instead completely privately owned.<ref name="MAS">{{cite web|url=http://www.keepirelandopen.org/Reeks_Report.pdf|title=MacGillycuddy Reeks Mountain Access Development Assessment|publisher=South Kerry Development Partnership|date=December 2013}}</ref>
==Hill walking==
[[File:Carrantuohill.jpg|thumb|Carrauntoohil (r) from Hag's Glen, with the ''Devil's Ladder'' path to the [[col]] between Carrauntoohil (r) and Cnoc na Toinne (l) visible in the distance]]
{{anchor|Devil's Ladder}}The straightforward route is via the ''Devil's Ladder'', which starts at ''Cronin's Yard'' ({{gbm4ibx|V837873}}) in the north-east, moves into the Hag's Glen, continues along between Lough Gouragh and Lough Calee, until the ''Devil's Ladder'', a worn path from the glen to the [[col]] between Carrauntoohil and [[Cnoc na Toinne]] {{convert|845|m|ft|abbr=on}} is visible.<ref name="jimr"/> No special climbing equipment is needed, but caution is advised as the ''Devil's Ladder'' has become unstable with overuse; alternatives to the ladder include the Bothar na Gige ''Zig Zag'' track (the north-east spur of Cnoc na Toinne 845 m (2,772 ft)).<ref name="jimr"/> The full route back to ''Cronin's Yard'' is 12–kilometres and takes 4–5 hours.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://outsider.ie/ireland/hiking-carrauntoohil-essential-information/|title=Hiking Carrauntoohil: Everything you Need to Know|publisher=Outsider|date=2018}}</ref><ref name="kmr">{{cite web|url=http://kerrymountainrescue.ie/carrauntoohil-route-descriptions/|title=Route Descriptions|publisher=Kerry Mountain Rescue Teams|date=2018}}</ref> Other popular, but more serious, routes to Carrauntoohil from the ''Hag's Glen'' are via the ''[[Hag's Tooth Ridge]]'' up to Beenkeragh, and then across the ''[[Beenkeragh Ridge]]'' to Carrauntoohil; or via the ''Eagle's Nest'' route to Lough Cummeenoughter, Ireland's highest lake, and up to the summit via ''Brother O'Shea's Gully'' or ''Curved Gully''.<ref name="kmr2"/><ref name="jimr"/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/life-and-style/travel/go-walk-curved-gully-carrauntoohil-co-kerry-1.1314431|title=Go walk: Curved Gully, Carrauntoohil, Co Kerry|date=23 February 2013|publisher=[[Irish Times]]|author=John G. O'Dwyer}}</ref>
[[File:Heavenly Gates (Carrauntoohil Mountain, Kerry, Ireland).jpg|thumb|''Heavenly Gates'' on the east-face. The 450 metre ''Howling Ridge'' rock-climb, starts at the ''Heavenly Gates''.]]
{{anchor|Heavenly Gates}}Instead of descending via the ''Devil's Ladder'', some climbers use a route known as the ''Heavenly Gates'', which starts above the [[col]] of the ''Devil's Ladder'' but takes a small stone path that cuts across the east-face of Carrauntoohil, through a narrow gap, known as the ''Heavenly Gates'' (see photo), and then heads diagonally down a deep gully to the base of the ''first level'' of ''Eagle's Nest'' corrie, where the Mountain Rescue Hut is situated.<ref name="jimr"/> This route, however, is hazardous, difficult to find as it is not marked, and particularly dangerous in poor visibility; it has been the source of several serious accidents on Carrauntoohil.<ref name="jimr"/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.irishexaminer.com/ireland/kerry-mountain-volunteers-risked-lives-to-retrieve-body-439908.html|title=Kerry mountain volunteers risked lives to retrieve body|publisher=[[Irish Examiner]]|date=20 January 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.ie/regionals/kerryman/news/man-dies-in-fall-on-reeks-34915015.html|title=Man dies in fall on Reeks|publisher=The Kerryman|date=30 July 2016|quote=Gardaí in Killarney said the man was alone when the accident happened at a section known as the Heavenly Gates. [..] Mr Wallace also said the area where the man fell is not normally frequented by walkers as it is a very steep rock face, adding the number of recorded incidents in the past 10 to 15 years at this section tended to be of a serious nature.}}</ref>
[[File:Carrauntoohil by Brother O'Shea's Gully.jpg|thumb|Climbing up ''Brother O'Shea's Gully'' with the ''Eagle's Nest'' (''third level''), and Lough Cummeenoughter below.]]
{{anchor|Coomloughra Horseshoe}}A strenuous undertaking is the 15–kilometre ''Coomloughra Horseshoe'', which takes 6–8 hours and is described as "one of Ireland’s classic ridge walks".<ref name="kmr"/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/life-and-style/travel/our-finest-mountain-route-1.788946|title=Our Nation's Finest Mountain Route|publisher=[[Irish Times]]|author=John O'Dwyer|date=20 June 2009|quote=There are a few candidates for this honour; Dingle’s Brandon Ridge, Connemara’s Glencoaghan Horseshoe and Mayo’s Mweelrea Circuit immediately spring to mind. But nearly all hillwalkers now agree that one route stands out above even such splendour. Kerry’s Coomloughra Horseshoe is virtually impossible to match in an Irish context, as it takes in our three highest summits and offers an adrenalin–filled crossing of a memorable mountain ridge, great long-range coastal views and a bird’s-eye panorama over some of Killarney’s renowned lakes and fells.}}</ref> It starts from the north-west up the ''Hydro-Track'' ({{gbm4ibx|V772871}}), and is usually done clockwise, first climbing Skregmore {{convert|848|m|ft|abbr=on}}, and then to [[Beenkeragh]] {{convert|1008|m|ft|abbr=on}}, across the famous ''Beenkeragh Ridge'', at the centre of which is [[The Bones]] {{convert|956|m|ft|abbr=on}}, and on to the summit of Carrauntoohil itself. The horseshoe is completed by continuing to [[Caher (mountain)|Caher]] {{convert|1000|m|ft|abbr=on}}, [[Caher West Top]] {{convert|973|m|ft|abbr=on}}, and descending to the starting point.<ref name="kmr"/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.corkbackpackers.ie/irelands-iconic-mountains/|title=Ireland’s Iconic Hillwalks – The Coomloughra Horseshoe|publisher=Cork Hill Walkers Club|date=2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://mountaintrails.ie/the-coomloughra-horseshoe-the-best-mountain-ridge-walk-in-ireland/|title=The Coomloughra Horseshoe – the best mountain ridge walk in Ireland?|publisher=Mountaintrails.ie|date=23 June 2014}}</ref>
==Rock and winter climbing==
[[File:Eagle's Nest (Lough Cummeenoughter) in Carrauntoohil in winter.jpg|thumb|Eagle's Nest and Lough Cummenoughter in winter]]
{{anchor|Howling Ridge}}Although the Reeks are not particularly known for their advanced rock climbing (e.g. unlike [[Ailladie]] in Clare, or [[Fair Head]] in Antrim), the east face of Carrauntoohil, looking into the ''Hag's Glen'', and the north-east face, looking into ''Brothers O'Shea's Gully'', have a number of multi-pitch, mixed route, rock climbing routes. The most well-known is the 450 m ''Howling Ridge'' (grade V–Diff) which starts at the base of the ''Heavenly Gates'', and takes the arete between Carrauntoohil's east and north-east faces.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.kerryclimbing.ie/howling-ridge/|title=Howling Ridge|publisher=KerryClimbing|date=2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.ie/life/travel/travel-tv/watch-the-incredible-howling-ridge-climb-on-irelands-highest-peak-36735648.html|title=Watch the incredible Howling Ridge climb on Ireland's highest peak|publisher=[[Irish Independent]]|date=23 March 2018}}</ref> The same faces are used for winter snow and ice climbing, conditions permitting, and 7 routes of Grade V are marked amongst almost 80 in total.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ukclimbing.com/logbook/crag.php?id=2023#guidebooks|title=Carrauntoohil Winter Climbs|publisher=UKClimbing.com|date=12 August 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://wiki.climbing.ie/index.php/Winter_Climbing_around_Carrauntoohil|title=Winter Climbing around Carrauntoohil|publisher=IrishClimbingWiki}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.kerryclimbing.ie/rock-climbing-guides-ireland/|title=Rock and Winder Guide: Carrauntoohil|publisher=KerryClimbing.ie|date=2017}}</ref>

{{pp-move-indef}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} {{infobox Organization |name=Cave Clan |image = Cave_clan_modern.svg |caption = Modern Cave Clan Logo. |formation = 1986 |website = http://www.caveclan.org }} The '''Cave Clan''' is a primarily [[Australia]]n group dedicated to [[urban exploration]].{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9FhRNhX9HOo&NR=1|title=Cave Clan|work=[[A Current Affair (Australian TV series)|A Current Affair]]|publisher=[[Nine Network]]|accessdate=18 March 2010}} ==History== The Cave Clan was founded on 26 January ([[Australia Day]]), 1986 by three [[Melbourne, Australia|Melbourne]] teenagers, Woody, Dougo and Sloth.{{Cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/rn/streetstories/stories/2004/1193089.htm|title=Cave Clan|accessdate=2 April 2007|publisher=StreetStories|year=2004}} The trio had started exploring together during the summer of 1985–1986.{{citation |last=Jurgensen |first=John |date=20 May 2001 |title=Urban Explorers Are Picture of Stealth |work=The Nation |page=A1}} Alfred Saddlier, a worker for the [[Melbourne and Metropolitan Board of Works]] (MMBW), is often cited as an inspiration to the Cave Clan's founders. During construction on Melbourne’s drains in the 1940s and 1950s, Saddlier would leave his name and the date in tar paint before the last section of tunnel was put in place. After Saddlier was mentioned in an article in Melbourne’s ''[[The Herald Sun]]'' {{Citation needed|date=April 2008}} his sister wrote to the Cave Clan explaining that her brother was in fact a "builder of drains", and not an explorer. ==Membership and activities== Cave Clan members explore natural or artificial tunnels and caves, along with rooftops and abandoned buildings. Their most frequent activities involve exploring underground [[stormwater]] [[Storm drain|drains]], bunkers, tunnels and forts.Brunero, Tim (22 January 2008) "[https://web.archive.org/web/20070517171313/http://livenews.com.au/Articles/2008/01/21/EXCLUSIVE_Drunk_vandals_or_intrepid_explorers_ Live News Exclusive – Drunk Vandals or Intrepid Explorers?]", livenews.com.au. Each chapter of the Cave Clan has its favourite locations with each city, each having a different history, with therefore different types of locations to explore. For example, in Sydney, sites the Cave Clan explore include an underground ex-naval oil reservoir in Sydney.BBC News Online: [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/low/programmes/from_our_own_correspondent/1822604.stm Subterranean Sydney], ''World: From Our Own Correspondent'', 16 February 2002[[Image:Hurcules pillars drain in Macquarie park, new south wales.jpg|thumb|A Sydney drain with urban explorers in view.]]Members of the Cave Clan come from various backgrounds including tradespersons, shop owners, teachers, government workers, writers, students, scientists, and mechanics;About the Cave Clan and What We Do, "[http://www.caveclan.org/aboutus.html About the Cave Clan and What We Do ]", Retrieved on 7 April 2008. with the Cave Clan acting as a uniting group for people who are interested in urban exploration in Australia. Amongst other things, members are attracted by the appeal of entering locations that the public rarely sees. ==Safety issues== The Cave Clan does not advocate entering drains when it is raining, exploring alone, or removing a manhole from beneath if the above location is unknown. This is due to the potential hazard of the exit being on a road and thus has the risk of being struck by a vehicle. The golden rule of the Cave Clan is, "When it rains, no drains!".{{Cite web|url=http://www.caveclan.org/safety.html|title=Safety|accessdate=2 April 2007|year=2007}} ==Controversy== [[File:Cave Clan Azimuth.gif|thumb|A modern compass themed Cave Clan logo.]] As with [[urban exploration]]-related topics, by entering into locations or drains without permission, the members of the Cave Clan can be described as "recreational trespassers". In 2005 it was revealed that the NSW State Government had asked for the Cave Clan's help in finding tunnels that could become terrorist targets.Cave Clan's Fortress, "[http://www.smh.com.au/news/national/cave-clans-fortress/2008/01/21/1200764136972.html Cave Clan's Fortress – smh.com.au]", Retrieved on 7 April 2008. Coroner Hugh Dillon investigating the death of two graffiti artists in a Sydney stormwater drain in 2008 has recommended police investigate a group known as the Sydney Cave Clan. Delivering his findings into the deaths, Dillon said he was concerned about the counter-cultural message by the group, which he said consisted of "shadowy characters". Dillon said he would recommend to police that they investigate the group and shut the website down after it was revealed that it publicised the drain and encouraged risk-taking activity. Malinowsky, the sole survivor of the trio, alleged at the inquest that he was encouraged by a website from the so-called "Cave Clan"—a group which he alleged dared people to explore urban underground spaces.{{cite news |url=http://abc.com.au/news/stories/2009/06/29/2611473.htm?section=justin |title=Investigate the Cave Clan: deaths inquest |work=abc.com.au |date=29 June 2009}}{{cite news |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090630104546/http://livenews.com.au/news/graffiti-deaths-spark-call-for-probe-into-cave-clan-group/2009/6/29/211431 |archivedate=30 June 2009 |url=http://www.livenews.com.au/news/graffiti-deaths-spark-call-for-probe-into-cave-clan-group/2009/6/29/211431 |title=Graffiti deaths spark call for probe into 'Cave Clan' group |work=livenews.com.au |date=29 June 2009}} ==Graffiti== [[Image:Cave Clan Tag Hobart Rivulet.jpg|right|thumb|A cave clan tag left underground in the [[Hobart]] Rivulet]] The Cave Clan has long officially distanced itself from [[graffiti]], despite the historical practice of discreet tagging as a historical documentation practice. Drain tagging is discouraged, especially in historically significant areas; there are clear examples, however, of the Cave Clan name, logo and other specific material related to the Cave Clan and/or their members, being used in graffiti, by unknown sources.{{cite news| last = Heathcote| first = Christopher| title = Discovering Graffiti| publisher = Art Monthly Australia| date = September 2000| url = http://www.melbournegraffiti.com/melbourne-graffiti_extras_history_discovering-graffiti.php | accessdate = 4 May 2012 }}{{cite news| last = Richardson| first = Owen| title = Stencil Graffiti Capital: Melbourne| publisher = The Age| date = 11 February 2006| url = http://www.theage.com.au/news/book-reviews/stencil-graffiti-capital-melbourne/2006/02/10/1139542386146.html| accessdate = 2 April 2007 }} The group accepts leaving details of an expedition in a plain section of the drain, tunnel or cavity to mark the place and time, and placing stickers above ground for promotional purposes. ==Cultural references== "Cave Clan" is the subject and title of a song released on the [[Mick Thomas]] album ''Spin! Spin! Spin!''. {{Cite web|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/work/31848686?selectedversion=NBD44209512|title=National Library of Australia|accessdate=9 December 2014|year=2014}}
"Cave Clan" is also a song by Neatly Folded Goat{{Cite web|url=https://play.google.com/store/music/album?id=B2ubkoejf4wyldydlxzg4k5bhse&tid=song-Tpsde7fru22643fm665h5mj7szy|title=Google Play|accessdate=27 March 2014|year=2015}}
In 2016, Australian record label Superconscious Records released "Cave Clan" by Melbourne producer [[Bjorn This Way]]. The song was a nostalgic tribute to the producer's experiences exploring drains and tunnels in the south eastern suburbs of Melbourne as a teenager.https://www.discogs.com/Bjorn-This-Way-Suco-Edits-Vol-2-/release/9057482 ==See also== {{commons category|Cave Clan sites}} * [[Urban exploration]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[https://www.caveclan.org/ Official website] [[Category:Clubs and societies in Australia]] [[Category:Subterranea (geography)]] [[Category:Urban exploration]]

[[File:Dead Vlei 4.jpg|thumb|Dead ''Acacia erioloba'' in Deadvlei]] '''Deadvlei''' is a white [[Claypan|clay pan]] located near the more famous salt pan of [[Sossusvlei]], inside the [[Namib-Naukluft Park]] in [[Namibia]]. Also written '''DeadVlei''' or '''Dead Vlei''', its name means "dead marsh" (from English ''dead'', and Afrikaans ''[[vlei]]'', a lake or marsh in a valley between the dunes). The pan also is referred to as "Dooie Vlei" which is the (presumably original) fully Afrikaans name. In Google there are many references to the site, its name often being translated erroneously in terms such as "dead valley"; a [[vlei]] is not a valley (which in Afrikaans is "vallei").<ref name="isbn0-624-00533-X">{{cite book |author1=Bosman, D. B. |author2=Van der Merwe I. W. |author3=Hiemstra, L. W. |lastauthoramp=yes |title=Tweetalige Woordeboek Afrikaans-Engels |publisher=Tafelberg-uitgewers |location= |year=1984 |pages= |isbn=0-624-00533-X |oclc= |doi= |accessdate=}}</ref> Nor is the site a valley; the pan is a desiccated vlei.
Dead Vlei has been claimed to be surrounded by the highest sand [[dune]]s in the world, the highest reaching 300–400 meters (350m on average, named "Big Daddy" or "Crazy Dune"), which rest on a [[sandstone]] terrace.
The clay pan was formed after rainfall, when the [[Tsauchab]] river flooded, creating temporary shallow pools where the abundance of water allowed [[Acacia erioloba|camel thorn trees]] to grow. When the climate changed, drought hit the area, and sand dunes encroached on the pan, which blocked the river from the area.
The trees died, as there no longer was enough water to survive. There are some species of plants remaining, such as [[salsola]] and clumps of [[Acanthosicyos horridus|nara]], adapted to surviving off the morning [[mist]] and very rare rainfall. The remaining skeletons of the trees, which are believed to have died 600–700 years ago (ca. 1340-1430), are now black because the intense sun has scorched them.<ref>{{cite journal |pages=769–82 |doi=10.1016/S0277-3791(01)00126-3 |title=How dry was dry?—Late Pleistocene palaeoclimates in the Namib Desert |year=2002 |last1=Lancaster |first1=Nicholas |journal=Quaternary Science Reviews |volume=21 |issue=7}}</ref><ref>Brook, G. A., P. Srivastava, and E. Marais (2006), Characteristics and OSL minimum ages of relict fluvial deposits near Sossus Vlei, Tsauchab River, Namibia, and a regional climate record for the last 30 ka, Journal of Quaternary Science, 21(4), 347-362, doi:10.1002/jqs.977</ref> Though not [[Petrified wood|petrified]], the wood does not decompose because it is so dry.<ref>{{cite book | author = Bridgeford, P & M| title = Touring Sesriem and Sossusvlei | publisher = P & M Bridgeford | location = Walvis Bay, Namibia | year = 2006 | isbn = 99916-30-77-5 }}</ref>
Films partly shot there include ''[[The Cell]]'' (starring [[Jennifer Lopez]]), ''[[The Fall (2006 film)|The Fall]]'', and ''[[Ghajini (2008 film)|Ghajini]]''.

page.title: Divisions of the world in Islam

revision.text:
{{Islam}}
The Arabic singular form ''dar'' ({{lang|ar|[[wikt:دار#Arabic|دار]]}}), translated literally, may mean "house", "abode", "structure", "place", "land", or "country". In [[Fiqh|Islamic jurisprudence]] it often refers to a part of the world.
The notions of "houses" or "divisions" of the world in [[Islam]] such as ''Dar al-Islam'' and ''Dar al-Harb'' does not appear in the Quran or the [[Hadith]].<ref name=Abdel-Haleem2010>{{cite book|last1=Abdel-Haleem|first1=Muhammad|authorlink=Muhammad Abdel-Haleem|title=Understanding the Qur'ān: Themes and Style|date=8 Sep 2010|publisher=I. B. Tauris & Co Ltd|isbn=978-1845117894|page=68}}</ref> According to [[Khaled Abou El Fadl|Abou El Fadl]], the only ''dar'' the Qur'an speaks of are "the abode of the Hereafter and the abode of the earthly life, with the former described as clearly superior to the latter".<ref name = kaef2007>{{cite book|last1=Abou El Fadl|first1=Khaled|authorlink=Khaled Abou El Fadl|title=The Great Theft: Wrestling Islam from the Extremists|date=January 23, 2007|publisher=HarperOne|isbn=978-0061189036|page=227}}</ref>
In classical [[Islamic law]], the major division are ''dar al-islam'' (lit. territory of Islam), denoting regions where Islamic law prevails,<ref>[http://www.oxfordislamicstudies.com/article/opr/t125/e491 Dar al-Islam] The Oxford Dictionary of Islam </ref> ''dar al-sulh'' (lit. territory of treaty) denoting non-Islamic lands which have concluded an armistice with a Muslim government,<ref>[http://www.oxfordislamicstudies.com/article/opr/t125/e496 Dar al-Sulh] The Oxford Dictionary of Islam</ref> and ''dar al-harb'' (lit. territory of war), denoting adjoining non-Islamic lands whose rulers are called upon to accept Islam.<ref name=ODI-harb>[http://www.oxfordislamicstudies.com/article/opr/t125/e490 Dar al-Harb] The Oxford Dictionary of Islam</ref>
Early Islamic jurists devised these terms to denote legal rulings for ongoing [[Muslim conquests]] almost a century after [[Muhammad]]. The first use of the terms was in Iraq by [[Abu Hanifa]] and his disciples [[Abu Yusuf]] and [[Al-Shaybani]]. Among those in the [[Levant]], [[Al-Awza'i]] was leading in this discipline and later [[Shafi'i]].
The concept of ''dar al-harb'' has been affected by the political fragmentation of the Muslim world and has little significance today.<ref name=ODI-harb/>
==Major religious divisions== [[File:Regions of the Lands of Islam by al-Muqaddasi.jpg|thumb|300px|right|The lands and cities of the Dar al-Islam in the 10th century, according to the geographer [[al-Muqaddasi]]]] ===Dar al-Islam=== '''''Dar al-Islam''''' ({{lang-ar|دار الإسلام}} literally ''house/abode of Islam''; or '''''Dar as-Salam''''', ''house/abode of Peace'';{{fact|date=June 2017}} or '''''Dar al-Tawhid''''', ''house/abode of monotheism'') is a term used by Muslim [[ulama|scholars]] to refer to those countries where Muslims can practice their religion as the ruling sect. It is the area of the world under the rule of Islam, literally, "the home of Islam."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mideastweb.org/Middle-East-Encyclopedia/dar-al-islam.htm|title=Dar al Islam|work=mideastweb.org}}</ref> These are usually Islamic cultures wherein Muslims represent the majority of the population, and so the government promises them a privileged status. Most ''Dar al-Islam'' areas are surrounded by other Islamic societies to ensure public protection.{{fact|date=December 2016}}
Some modern Muslim scholars believe that the labeling of a country or place as being a part of ''Dar al-Islam'' revolves around the question of religious security. This means that if a Muslim practices Islam freely in his place of abode, even though that place happens to be secular or un-Islamic, then he will be considered as living in the ''Dar al-Islam''. Yet, the majority opinion, which relies on tradition, claims that only countries ruled by Sharia can be considered true "abodes of peace."{{fact|date=June 2017}}
''Dar al-Islam'', or house/abode of Submission, is also known and referred to as ''Dar al-Salam'', or house/abode of Peace. The term appears in the [[Quran]] in 10.25 and 6.127 as a name of [[Jannah|Paradise]].<ref>''The [[Encyclopaedia of Islam]]''. New Edition. Brill, Leiden. Vol. 2, p. 128</ref>
According to [[Abu Hanifa]], considered to be the originator of the concept, the requirements for a country to be part of ''Dar al-Islam'' are:<ref name=fatwa>[http://www.islamonline.net/servlet/Satellite?pagename=IslamOnline-English-Ask_Scholar/FatwaE/FatwaE&cid=1119503544498 Fatwa by Sheikh `Atiya Saqr, former head of Al-Azhar Fatwa Committee, about the concept of Dar al-Harb and Dar al-Islam] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071206011857/http://www.islamonline.net/servlet/Satellite?pagename=IslamOnline-English-Ask_Scholar%2FFatwaE%2FFatwaE |date=2007-12-06 }}</ref><ref name=khalil>{{cite web|url=http://english.islamway.com/bindex.php?section=article&id=211 |title=Ahmed Khalil: "Dar Al-Islam And Dar Al-Harb: Its Definition and Significance" |publisher=English.islamway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-03-13}}</ref> # Muslims must be able to enjoy peace and security with and within this country. # The country should be ruled by a Muslim government.<ref name="mdernpers">Black, E. A., Esmaeili, H., & Hosen, N. (2013). Modern Perspectives on Islamic Law. Edward Elgar Publishing. Retrieved from https://books.google.com/books?id=2kngBY-Gu18C&pg=PA42&lpg=PA42&dq=what+countries+are+in+dar+ul+islam?&source=bl&ots=pRHhuwunsg&sig=hB1MVTYkAWbTSnLlEf6w3OBS3R8&hl=en&sa=X&ei=3kwYVa-DKcqdyATNl4KYDQ&ved=0CEkQ6AEwCTgK#v=onepage&q=what%20countries%20are%20in%20dar%20ul%20islam%3F&f=false</ref> # It has common frontiers with some Muslim countries.
===Dar al-Harb=== '''''Dar al-Harb''''' ({{lang-ar|دار الحرب|links=no}} "house of war". Dar al-Harb is a term classically referring to those countries which do not have a treaty of nonaggression or peace with Muslims (those that do are called Dar al-'Ahd or Dar al-Sulh). <ref name="oxfordislamicstudies.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.oxfordislamicstudies.com/article/opr/t125/e490?_hi=17&_pos=3|title=Dar al-Harb|work=oxfordislamicstudies.com}}</ref>
According to [[Majid Khadduri]], the fundamental distinction between ''Dar al-Islam'' and ''Dar al-Harb'' was introduced after the defeat of the [[Umayyad Caliphate]] at [[Battle of Tours]] in 732 which prevented the expansion of Islam to the north, while at the same time the expansion of the caliphate to the east had been halted.<ref>{{cite book|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=4v4cCgAAQBAJ&q=732#v=onepage&f=false|title= Muslims and Modernity: Current Debates|author= [[Clinton Bennet]]|publisher= [[Bloomsbury Publishing]]|year= 2005|page= 158|isbn= 9781441100504}}</ref>
[[Wahbah al-Zuhayli]] argues that the concept of Dar al-Harb is mostly historical: "The existence of Dār al-Islām and Dār al-Ḥarb in contemporary times is rare or extremely limited. This is because Islamic countries have joined the United Nations covenant that stipulates relationship between nations is peace and not war. Therefore non-Muslim countries are Dār al-‘Ahd …"<ref>Al-Zuhaylī, Al-Mu‘āmalāt al-Māliyyah, p. 255.</ref>
===Dar al-'Ahd, Dar al-Sulh=== '''Dar al-'Ahd''' ({{lang-ar|دار العهد|links=no}} "house of truce") or '''Dar al-[[Sulh]]''' ({{lang-ar|دار الصلح|links=no}} "house of conciliation/treaty") are terms used for territories that have a treaty of non-aggression or peace with Muslims. <ref name="oxfordislamicstudies.com"/>
This designation can be found in the Quran, where Muslims are directed on how they should act in war:
"Excepting those who join a people between whom and you there is a treaty, or such as come to you with hearts reluctant to fight you, or to fight their own people. Had Allah wished, He would have imposed them upon you, and then they would have surely fought you. So if they keep out of your way and do not fight you, and offer you peace, then Allah does not allow you any course [of action] against them." [https://quran.com/4/90 Quran 4:90]
==See also== {{Portal|Islam}} *[[Ummah]] *[[Caliphate]] *[[Dhimmi]] *[[Sulh]] *[[Pan-Islamism]] *[[Islamic studies]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== * {{EI3|last=Albrecht|first=Sarah|title=Dār al-Islām and dār al-ḥarb|year=2016|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1163/1573-3912_ei3_COM_25867}} *''Western Muslims and the Future of Islam'', by [[Tariq Ramadan]] *''[[Fatwa on Terrorism]] and Suicide Bombings'', by [[Muhammad Tahir-ul-Qadri]] *[https://archive.org/details/NicolaMelisMollaHusrevKitabAlJihad Nicola Melis, ''Trattato sulla guerra. Il'' Kitab al-gihad ''di Molla Husrev''. Cagliari: Aipsa, 2002]. * König, Daniel G., Arabic-Islamic Views of the Latin West. Tracing the Emergence of Medieval Europe, Oxford, OUP, 2015.
==External links== *[http://www.shaikhsiddiqui.com/islam.html Sects in Islam]

{{Infobox lake | name = Drevviken | image = Gudö å.jpg | caption = The outlet stream Gudö å | image_bathymetry = | caption_bathymetry = | location = | coords = {{coord|59|14|44|N|18|7|28|E|region:SE_type:waterbody|display=inline,title}} | type = | inflow = [[Lissmaån]], [[Forsån]], [[Magelungen]], [[Orlången]], [[Dammträsk]] | outflow = [[Gudö å]], [[Långsjön, Skälsätra-Tutviken|Långsjön]] | catchment = {{convert|4,897|ha|abbr=on}} | basin_countries = Sweden | length = | width = | area = {{convert|571|ha|abbr=on}} | depth = {{convert|6.7|m|abbr=on}} | max-depth = {{convert|15.2|m|abbr=on}} | volume = {{convert|37|e6m3|acre.ft|abbr=on}} | residence_time = 10-11 months | shore = | elevation = {{convert|19.3|m|abbr=on}} | frozen = | islands = | cities = [[Stockholm]] | reference = <ref name="vattenprogram-10.1">Vattenprogram, p 10.1</ref> }} '''Drevviken''' is a [[lake]] in southern [[Stockholm]], [[Sweden]], shared by the four municipalities Stockholm, [[Haninge Municipality|Haninge]], [[Huddinge Municipality|Huddinge]], and [[Tyresö Municipality|Tyresö]].
While much of the surrounding area is used for one-family houses, the lake and the green space north of it are considered to be of great recreational and natural importance and forms part of a suggested nature reserve around lake [[Flaten]]. <ref name="Drevviken">Drevviken</ref>
== Catchment area == Approximately two third of the catchment area is occupied by settlements, mostly one-family houses. Three major industrial areas are located within the catchment area which is mostly dominated by forests with minor open grasslands. North of the lake is a [[deciduous forest]] containing [[herbaceous plant]]s and [[rock (geology)|rocks]] covered with [[wikt:brushwood|brushwood]]s and [[lichen]]. Additionally, there is a [[Fluvio-glacial deposition|fluvio-glacial deposit]] with a [[irrigation|broad irrigated]] marsh and a scenic [[pine|pine forest]]; and a [[wetland]] which is the remnant of a former [[stream]].<ref name="vattenprogram-10.3">Vattenprogram, p 10.3-10.6</ref>
=== Environmental influence === [[Stormwater]] from several suburbs empties into the lake around which are three [[allotment (gardening)|allotment-gardens]]. Potentially hazardous activities in the area include a petrol station, an asphalt works, concrete industry, small scale industries, and a closed stock pile covering 9 hectare containing excavated material from the demolition of a major area in central Stockholm in the 1960s. Several traffic routes and a metro track passes through the catchment area.<ref name="vattenprogram-10.3" />
== Flora and fauna == During summers [[phytoplankton]] are dominated by [[cyanobacteria]] and occasionally [[diatom]]s, most commonly ''Aphanizomenon cf gracile'' but also ''Pseudanabaena limnetica'', ''Planktolyngbya sp.'' and various species of ''[[Anabaena]]'', of whom only ''[[Aphanizomenon]]'' is potentially poisonous and ''Anabaena'' frequently causes [[algal bloom]]. [[Carapace]] [[flagellate]]s such as ''[[Ceratium hirundinella]]'' and various [[dinoflagellate]]s, are few but important to the lake's [[biomass]]. Various [[rotifer]]s are common [[zooplankton]] but [[cyclopoida|cyclopoid]] [[copepod]]s can also be found. An inventory of [[aquatic plant]]s in the lake in 1998 resulted in a list of some 30 species, including [[Sparganium|branched bur-reed]] and [[Elodea|Nuttall's waterweed]] (the latter introduced in Europe during the 20th century and relatively new in Sweden.)<ref name="vattenprogram-10.6">Vattenprogram, p 10.6-10.7</ref>
A list of [[Dragonfly]] larvae produced in 2000 included [[red-eyed damselfly|red-eyed]], [[variable damselfly|variable]], and [[blue-tailed damselfly|blue-tailed damselflies]]. Sample fishing in 1997 documented a dozen species, most notably [[Rutilus|roach]] and [[zander]] but also [[northern pike]], [[perch]], [[eel]], [[trout]], - of which some have been introduced into the lake - and many others. The lake was struck by [[crayfish plague]] in 1950 but [[crayfish]] was reintroduced around 1970. North-east of the lake [[smooth newt]], [[common frog]], and [[common toad]] were documented in 1996. [[Common noctule|Noctule bats]] documented in the area, previously assigned the [[Conservation status|status]] [[near-threatened]], are now considered [[least concern]]. [[Soprano pipistrelle]] has also been seen along the northern shore of the lake. Couples of [[great crested grebe]]s and [[common tern]]s are breeding by the lake together with colonies of [[black-headed gull]]s, [[mute swan]]s, [[Canada goose|Canada geese]], [[European herring gull|herring gulls]], and [[lesser black-backed gull]]s.<ref name="vattenprogram-10.6" />
== See also == * [[Geography of Stockholm]] * [[Lakes of Sweden]] * [[Drevviken Party]]

[[File:Azerbaijan forest 3.JPG|thumb|right|300px|[[Caucasus mixed forest]] in the [[Quba District (Azerbaijan)|Quba District]]]] [[File:Azerbaijan forests map.png|thumb|right|300px|Map showing forest distribution in Azerbaijan]] [[File:Lerik Azerbaijan 03.JPG|thumb|right|300px|[[Caspian Hyrcanian mixed forest]] in the [[Lerik District]]]] The total [[forest]] area of [[Azerbaijan]] is 1,021,880 [[hectare|ha]] or 11.8% of the country's area.<ref name="Eco">{{cite web|title=Forests of the Republic of Azerbaijan|url=http://eco.gov.az/en/86-the-forests-of-the-republic|publisher=[[Ministry of Ecology and Natural Resources (Azerbaijan)|Ministry of Ecology and Natural Resources of Azerbaijan]]|accessdate=29 January 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|date=2017-12-01|title=Beech forests of Azerbaijan: The modern condition, age structure and regeneration|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1512188716300549|journal=Annals of Agrarian Science|language=en|volume=15|issue=4|pages=453–457|doi=10.1016/j.aasci.2016.08.003|issn=1512-1887}}</ref> The forest [[biome]]s consist of [[temperate deciduous forest]]s, [[temperate broadleaf and mixed forests]], [[temperate coniferous forest]]s and [[riparian forest]]s.<ref name="Eco"/> Specialists estimate that in the [[8th century|8th]]-[[9th century|9th centuries]] the [[forest cover]] was around 30-35%, most of it situated in mountainous areas.<ref name="Eco"/><ref>{{Cite book|title=GARDENS of BIODIVERSITY: Conservation of genetic resources and their use in traditional food production systems by small farmers of the Southern Caucasus|last=Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations|first=|publisher=Food & Agriculture Org.|year=2018|isbn=9251066132|location=|pages=}}</ref>
While as a whole, Azerbaijan is a country with modest forest cover, the forest cover is unevenly spread across the country. In the low-lying areas, the forest cover is very sparse, also due to the fact that the precipitation is too low for trees and forests to grow in most of these areas; whereas in many mountainous areas, the forest cover is much greater especially in wetter areas.<ref name="Eco"/>
49% of the country's forests are located in the [[Greater Caucasus Mountains]], 34% in the [[Lesser Caucasus Mountains]], 15% in the [[Talysh Mountains]]-[[Lankaran Lowland]] region, 2% in the [[Kur-Araz Lowland]], and 0.5% in the [[Nakhchivan Autonomous Republic]].<ref name="Eco"/>
The forests are classified into two major [[ecoregion]]s in Azerbaijan: the [[Caucasus mixed forests]] of the Greater Caucasus Mountains and the Lesser Caucasus Mountains, and the [[Caspian Hyrcanian mixed forests]] of the Talysh Mountains-Lankaran Lowland region.
==Flora== Azerbaijan preserves many [[endemic]] [[tree]] and [[shrub]] species, relicts of the [[Tertiary]] period which were not affected by [[Pliocene]] and [[Pleistocene]] [[glaciation]]s.
The forests of Azerbaijan account for 150 endemic species of trees and bushes out of 435 species of trees and bushes. Some endemic tree species are, the Hyrcanian box tree (''[[Buxus hyrcana]]''), Caucasian pear (''[[Pyrus communis]] subsp. caucasica''), Lenkoran acacia (''[[Albizia julibrissin]]''), chestnut-leaved oak (''[[Quercus castaneifolia]]''), Caucasian oak (''[[Quercus macranthera]]''), Caucasian ash (''[[Fraxinus angustifolia]]'' subsp. ''oxycarpa''), European ash (''[[Fraxinus excelsior]]''), European hornbeam (''[[Carpinus betulus]]''), Oriental hornbeam (''[[Carpinus orientalis]]''), Oriental beech (''[[Fagus orientalis]]''), Caucasian persimmon (''[[Diospyros lotus]]''), Caspian locust tree (''[[Gleditsia caspica]]''), Caucasian alder (''[[Alnus subcordata]]''), black alder (''[[Alnus glutinosa]]'' subsp.'' barbata''), white poplar (''[[Populus alba]]'') Caucasian wingnut (''[[Pterocarya fraxinifolia]]''), Persian ironwood (''[[Parrotia persica]]''), Caucasian zelkova (''[[Zelkova carpinifolia]]''), butcher's broom (''[[Ruscus aculeatus]]''), velvet maple (''[[Acer velutinum]]''), Cappadocian maple (''[[Acer cappadocicum]]''), wych elm (''[[Ulmus glabra]]''), Caucasian lime tree (''[[Tilia dasystyla]]'' subsp. ''caucasica''), wild cherry (''[[Prunus avium]]''), wild service tree (''[[Sorbus torminalis]]''), sweet chestnut (''[[Castanea sativa]]''), Nordmann fir (''[[Abies nordmanniana]]'') among many others.
=== Floristic diversity === Extensive territories are covered with wormwood ephemeral and halophytic vegetation in [[Absheron Peninsula|Absheron peninsular]], [[Qobustan (town)|Kobustan]], Kura-Araxinskaya lowlands, and foothills and plains of [[Nakhchivan Autonomous Republic|Nakhchivan]]. There are different kinds of shrubs and bushes on salinized soils such as [[Salsola|Salsola arbuscular]], [[Kalidium|Kolidium]], [[Salicornia]], and Holocnemum strobelaceum. [[Tamarix]] and wild [[sorghum]] bushes spread along the lowlands.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=Cooperation in the European Mountains: The Caucasus|last=Price|first=Martin|publisher=IUCN|year=2000|isbn=2831705347|location=Switzerland|pages=}}</ref>
In the west region of Azerbaijan, of which lands are dry-plain and semi-dessert, there exist sparse forests. Those forests include [[Juniper|Juniperus]] oblonga, [[Pine|Pinus]] eldarica, and [[pistachio]]. Since the groundwater is highly available in the [[Samur, Azerbaijan|Samur]] – [[Şabran|Davachi]] lowlands, Alazan – Agritchay valley, and [[Karabakh]] plains, lowland forests in those areas are widespread. Oak, apsen, and poplar can be found in those forests.<ref name=":0" />
There are broadleaf forests on the slopes of the mountains in the [[Greater Caucasus]] and [[Lesser Caucasus]], which include [[beech]], white beech, ash, [[maple]], eastern [[oak]], and Iberian oak. The [[Talysh Mountains|Talysh mountains]] have relic flora with broadleaf forests. [[Albizia julibrissin|Albizia jilibrissin]], [[Zelkova]], and [[Parrotia|Parrotia persika]] can be found in the forests of the Talysh mountains.<ref name=":0" /> {| class="wikitable" | colspan="3" |'''Floristic diversity in Azerbaijan'''<ref name=":0" /> |- |'''Forests''' |'''Typical flora''' |'''Valuable flora''' |- |Beech forests |Maple and beech |<nowiki>-</nowiki> |- |Marsh forests |Ephedra, juniper, and Christ’s thorn |Kokh pine and bearded aspen |- |Oak – beech forests |Caucasus white beech, Georgian oak, and eastern beech |Trautfetter maple and plane |- |Oak forests on carbonate soils |White beech and oak |Hazelnut, persimmon, and berry yew |- |Relic sub-tropical forests |Eastern beech, Caucasus beech, and chestnut oak |Iron tree |- |Tugai forests |Salsola, reed, soleras, and sarsazan |<nowiki>-</nowiki> |- |Girkan forests |<nowiki>-</nowiki> |Box tree and Albizia |}
== Mountain forests ==
=== Greater Caucasus Mountains === [[File:Qax rayonu 0134.JPG|thumb|300x300px|Mountain forests in [[Qakh District|Gakh]]]]
==== Mountain forests in Gakh ==== Mountain forests of [[Qakh District|Gakh]] region are located in the southern side of the Greater Caucasus in west of Azerbaijan. There are forests territories from 350 to 2000 meters above sea level on the mountains. Caucasian Hornbeam ([[Carpinus caucasica]]) Georgian Oak ([[Quercus iberica]]) are dominant trees on the dry and warm areas of the mountains. Oriental Hornbeam (Carpinus orientalis) and Oriental Beech ([[Fagus orientalis]]) are widespread on the dry lands of the mountains. The timberline includes Trautvetter’s Maple ([[Acer trautvetteri]]) and Persian Oak ([[Quercus macranthera]]). In the mountain forests of Gakh, there can be found Tree Hazel ([[Corylus iberica]]), which is an endemic species, and only specific to the western territories of the country.<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|title=Potential Analysis for Further Nature Conservation in Azerbaijan: A Spatial and Political Investment Strategy|last=Schmidt|first=Sebastian|publisher=Geozon Science Media|year=2009|isbn=3941971018|location=Greifswald|pages=}}</ref>
==== Mountain forests in Oguz ==== Mountain forests in [[Oghuz District|Oguz]] are situated in the eastern Greater Caucasus. From 650 to 1900 meters above sea level, forests areas are located. The trees that are specific to Oguz forests are Caucasian Oak (Quercus iberica), Persian Oak (Quercus macranthera), Caucasian Hornbeam (Carpinus caucasica), and Oriental Beech (Fagus orientalis).<ref name=":1" />
==== Mountain forests in Altiaghaj ==== Scrublands and sparse forests are particular for the region that is located in the eastern Greater Caucasus. Juniper shrubs can be found in [[Altıağac|Altiaghaj]]. Their height reaches to 4 meters. There are other ligneous types of plants such as Viburnum lantana, Spirea crenata, and Berberis vulgaris. 1300 meters above sea level, hornbeam forests are distributed.<ref name=":1" />
=== Lesser Caucasus Mountains ===
==== Mountain forests in Shamkir ==== Forests are situated in the Shamkirchay valley, which is the part of the northern side of Lesser Caucasus. They are mainly distributed along the riversides, where water resources are rich. There are different maple species, walnut, and hackberry in these forests. Christ’s Thorn, pomegranate, and juniper also can be found on the slope areas. In [[Shamkir District|Shamkir]], there are different type of forests such as beech and beech-hornbeam forests, pear-maple forests, and Georgian Oak-hornbeam forests. Plum, hawthorn, apple, medlar, and pear can be found on scrublands.<ref name=":1" />
=== Talysh Mountains ===
==== Hirkanian forest ==== Hirkanian forests cover the territories of both [[Azerbaijani language|Azerbaijan]] and [[Iran]]. The area of Hirkanian forests is approximately 0.1 million ha in Azerbaijan. Hirkan National Park was settled in the Talysh mountains, which covers about 38000 ha territory enclosing different zones of forest.<ref name=":1" />
The Caspian forests is a part of Hirkanian forest province. In these forests, there can be found some endemic trees such as Albizzia julibrissin, Parrotia persica, Quercus castaneifolia, and Gleditsia capsica. Peculiarity of this forest is that, there are various species of plants that include 211 species of shrub and semi-shrub, 90 species of tree, and approximately 1500 vascular plant species. Other than that, Chestnut-leaved Oak, Date Plum, Zelkovie, Caucasian Wing-nut, Velvet maple, Oriental Beech, and Perian Oak can be found in Hirkanian forest. There are also various evergreen species of trees exist such as Ilex spingera, Buxus hyrcana, and Danae racemose.<ref name=":1" />
==== Zuvand ==== [[Yeni Zuvand|Zuvand]] region is situated near Lerik district. The area is semi-desert, therefore, the vegetation in Zuvand is durable for drought. In the large areas of Zuvan forests, there is Frigana vegetation, which has three groups. First group includes Astragalus meyerii, aureus, and persicus. The second group is Acantholymon and the third group is Onobrychus. Quercus macrantera and Fagus orientalis are also specific to these forests.<ref name=":1" />
==Management and protection== All forests are owned by the state and are under the management of the [[Ministry of Ecology and Natural Resources (Azerbaijan)|Ministry of Ecology and Natural Resources of Azerbaijan]], and forest land usage is limited by law and industrial cutting is forbidden. The "Forest Code" of the Republic of Azerbaijan and the "Law of the Azerbaijan Republic on Environmental Protection" are the main legal documents regulating the protection and management of forests in the country.<ref name="ENPI">{{cite web|title=Forests of Azerbaijan|url=http://www.enpi-fleg.az/foresters/forests-of-azerbaijan/|publisher=[[ENPI]]|accessdate=29 January 2016}}</ref>
The "National Program on restoration and expansion of forests in the Azerbaijani Republic" adopted for the period 2003-2008 contributed partially to the improvement of the situation: over the last 6 years forest restoration actions were carried out on more than 71,634 hectares of forest land, and a large number of trees were planted. According to the Forest Development Department of the Ministry of Ecology and Natural Resources of Azerbaijan during the 2013 large-scale forest restoration activities were carried out at the territory of 1031 ha.<ref name="ENPI"/>
There are two main departments that are dealing with forestry issues under the Ministry of Ecology and Natural Resources in Azerbaijan. Forestry Development Department deals with the management of the lands and resources of forests, and Department of Biodiversity and Protected Natural Ares manages the protected forests.<ref name=":2">National Forest Program (2013). ''[http://www.fao.org/forestry/39774-0e03f4576d53ec8aeeba6da1d02f63922.pdf Forest Policy Statement and the Action Plan 2015-2030.]''</ref>
=== Forestry Development Department === The responsibilities of the department include restoration and preservation of forests. There are five divisions within the department. The department has 33 enterprises that deal with rehabilitation and protection of forests, 2 enterprises of afforestation, and 6 forests nurseries. Forestry Scientific Research Institute is a unit of the departments and deals with forestry.<ref name=":2" />
==Problems== The Azerbaijani forests experience problems of different characters. Most of them are linked with the lack of awareness among the local population on issues of sustainable [[forest management]], impact of [[climate change]] on the forests and the insufficient enforcement of existing laws on [[forest protection]].<ref name="ENPI"/>
The occupation of the part of the country's territory by Armenia ([[Nagorno-Karabakh]] and the [[Armenian-controlled territories surrounding Nagorno-Karabakh|territories surrounding it]]) caused a significant damage to the forests, especially those located in the mountainous areas.<ref name="ENPI"/>
Another critical problem is the continuous practice of illegal grazing for [[firewood]] in the forests which are damaging the [[biodiversity]] and are resulting in economic and social losses. [[Illegal logging]] remains a challenge for the Azerbaijani forest sector since country’s independence.<ref name="ENPI"/>
Due to the poor management in many regions, and especially villages located in proximity to the forests, acts of illegal logging exist and pose a significant threat to the forests. The same threat comes from the unsustainable tourism and recreation practices. At the same time the forests of Azerbaijan feel the impact of the global climate change with an increase of [[forest fire]]s during the summer.<ref name="ENPI"/>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== {{Commons category|Forests in Azerbaijan}} * [http://eco.gov.az Ministry of Ecology and Natural Resources of Azerbaijan] {{az icon}} {{en icon}}

[[Geographic information system]]s (GISs) have become a useful and important tool in the field of [[hydrology]] to study and manage Earth's [[water resources]]. Climate change and greater demands on water resources require a more knowledgeable disposition of arguably one of our most vital resources. Because water in its occurrence varies spatially and temporally throughout the [[hydrologic cycle]], its study using GIS is especially practical. Whereas previous GIS systems were mostly static in their geospatial representation of hydrologic features, GIS platforms are becoming increasingly dynamic, narrowing the gap between historical data and current hydrologic reality.
The elementary [[water cycle]] has inputs equal to outputs plus or minus change in storage. Hydrologists make use of this hydrologic budget when they study a [[Drainage basin|watershed]]. The inputs in a hydrologic budget include [[Precipitation (meteorology)|precipitation]], surface flow, and groundwater flow. Outputs consist of [[evapotranspiration]], [[infiltration (hydrology)|infiltration]], [[surface runoff]], and surface/groundwater flows. All of these quantities can be measured or estimated based on environmental data and their characteristics can be graphically displayed and studies using GIS.
==GIS in surface water== [[Image:Real time gages ne.jpg|thumb|right|420px|USGS Real-Time streamflow gage locations with hyperlinks within a GIS to the data]] In the field of [[hydrological modeling]], analysis generally begins with the sampling and measurement of existing hydrologic areas. In this stage of research, the scale and accuracy of measurements are key issues<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Clark|first1=Michael|title=Putting water in its place: a perspective on GIS in hydrology and water management|journal=Hydrological Processes|date=May 1998|volume=12|issue=6|doi=10.1002/(SICI)1099-1085(199805)12:6<823::AID-HYP656>3.0.CO;2-Z}}</ref>. Data may either be collected in the field or through online research. The [[United States Geological Survey]] ((USGS)) is a publicly available source of [[Remote sensing|remotely sensed]] hydrological data. Historical and real-time streamflow data are also available via the internet from sources such as the [[National Weather Service]] (NWS) and the [[United States Environmental Protection Agency]] (EPA). A benefit of using GIS softwares for hydrological modeling is that digital visualizations of data can be linked to real-time data. For surface water modeling, [[digital elevation models|digital elevation model]] are often layered with hydrographic data in order to determine the boundaries of a watershed<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Naidu|first1=Dadi|title=Use of GIS in Hydrological Investigations|journal=International Journal of Interdisciplinary Advanced Research Trends|date=December 2015|volume=II|issue=2|url=http://ijmart.in/PreviousIssues/Dec%202015/11.pdf}}</ref> . Understanding these boundaries is integral to understanding where precipitation runoff will flow. For example, in the event of [[snowmelt]], the amount of snowfall can be input into GIS to predict the amount of water that will travel downstream <ref>{{cite journal|last1=Naidu|first1=Dadi|title=Use of GIS in Hydrological Investigations|journal=International Journal of Interdisciplinary Advanced Research Trends|date=December 2015|volume=II|issue=2|url=http://ijmart.in/PreviousIssues/Dec%202015/11.pdf}}</ref>. This information has applications in local government asset management, [[agriculture]] and [[environmental science]]. Another useful application for GIS regards [[flood risk assessment]]. Using digital elevation models combined with peak discharge data can predict which areas of a floodplain will be submerged depending on the amount of rainfall. In a study of the Illinois River watershed, Rabie (2014)<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Rabie|first1=Anas|title=Integrating GIS and hydrology for flood risk analysis|date=2014}}</ref> found that a decently accurate flood risk map could be generated using only DEMs and [[stream gauge]] data. It should be noted that analysis based on these two parameters alone does not account for manmade developments including levees or drainage systems, and therefore should not be considered a comprehensive result.
[[Image:Dem.jpg|thumb|right|300px|A digital elevation model (DEM) from which a watershed may be delineated within a GIS]]
==GIS in groundwater==
The use of GIS to analyze groundwater falls into the field of [[hydrogeology]]. Since 98% of available freshwater on Earth is groundwater<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Naidu|first1=Dadi|title=Use of GIS in Hydrological Investigations|journal=International Journal of Multidisciplinary Advanced Research Trends|date=December 2015|volume=2|issue=2}}</ref>, the need to effectively model and manage these resources is apparent. As the demand for groundwater continues to increase with the world’s [[overpopulation|growing population]], it is vital that these resources be properly managed. Indeed, when groundwater usage is not monitored sufficiently, it may result in damage to aquifers or [[groundwater-related subsidence]], as occurred in the Ogallala aquifer in the United States. In some cases, GIS can be used to analyze drainage and groundwater data in order to select suitable sites for groundwater recharge<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Saraf|first1=A. K.|last2=Choudhury|first2=P. R.|title=Integrated remote sensing and GIS for groundwater exploration and identification of artificial recharge sites|journal=International Journal of Remote Sensing|date=25 Nov 2010|volume=19|issue=10|doi=10.1080/014311698215018}}</ref>. [[Image:Ogallala changes in feet 1980-1995 USGS.gif|thumb|right|360px|Groundwater level change of the High Plains Aquifer, 1980–95]]
==References== {{reflist}} *Girish Kumar, M., Bali, R. and Agarwal, A.K (2009). GIS Integration of remote sensing and electrical data for hydrological exploration- A case study of Bhakar watershed, India. Hydrological Sciences Journal 54 (5) pp 949–960. * Dingman, S. Lawrence, Physical Hydrology, Prentice-Hall, 2nd Edition, 2002 * Fetter, C.W. Applied Hydrogeology, Prentice-Hall, 4th Edition, 2001 * Maidment, David R., ed. Arc Hydro: GIS for Water Resources, ESRI Press, 2002
==See also== *[[GIS in environmental contamination]] *[[Geographic information system]] *[[ArcGIS]] *[[GIS and aquatic science]]
==External links== * [http://spatialhydrology.com/ Spatial Hydrology] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070420083108/http://gislounge.com/ll/hydrology.shtml GIS Lounge] * [http://www.esri.com/news/arcnews/spring03articles/in-japan.html ArcNews Online] * [http://www.agc.army.mil/ US Army Geospatial Center] — For information on OCONUS surface water and groundwater.
